Award.AwardTitle: 38th Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports participation in the thirty-eighth annual Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE) at the University of North Georgia in Oakwood, Georgia, on October 6-7, 2018. Since its origin in 1981 at Virginia Tech, the conference has rotated among institutions in the southeast region of the United States. The main purpose of the conference is to promote research and education in the theory and applications of differential equations and the related numerical computations in many areas of science. Experts, beginning researchers, and graduate students will be brought together to share their research and develop a research network. Graduate students, university professors, and mathematicians who work in different industries from the southeastern region will particularly benefit from the conference; and women, minority, and underrepresented groups are strongly encouraged to participate in SEARCDE. Further information about the conference can be found at https://ung.edu/mathematics/searcde.

The goal of SEARCDE is to foster an environment for the exchange of ideas and the discussion of recent developments in the field. The thirty-eighth SEARCDE will focus on the application of differential equations in fluid dynamics, environmental change, and the related computational methods guiding high performance and parallel computing. Graduate students and beginning researchers will have opportunities to learn about progress in their field from experts, present their research, receive feedback, explore future directions, and develop collaborative projects. Three plenary speakers will deliver a one-hour lecture each at the conference, and all other participants will have an opportunity to present a twenty-minute talk on their research. There will also be an open forum led by experts that will foster discussion and collaboration among participants

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 38th Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations was held on the Gainesville Campus of the University of North Georgia (UNG) October 6-7, 2018. The university hosted this conference series for the first time. The primary objective of the conference was to promote research and education in the fields of both pure and applied analysis of differential equations by bringing together established and beginning researchers, advanced undergraduate and graduate students as well as recent PhDs.

 The conference featured three one-hour plenary talks, three thirty-minute invited talks and 74 twenty-minute parallel contributed talks. The plenary talks were delivered by Peter Constantin from Princeton University, Irene Gamba from the University of Texas at Austin and Ratnasingham Shivaji from the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. All three are internationally recognized experts in their field of study. The plenary talks highlighted the history, recent developments, and future issues in differential equations and their applications including singularities in fluids, infinite semipositone problems, the Cauchy problems and BEC stability for the quantum Boltzmann-Condensation System at very low temperature. The invited talks were delivered by renowned mathematicians and the contributed talks were delivered by the PhD students and early career mathematicians. The invited and parallel talks were grouped in several categories including the theory, applications, and numerical simulations of differential equations arising from a wide range of physical, biological, and economic systems.

There were 120 registered participants as well as several UNG faculty and student volunteers. Each talk was attended by a significant number of conference participants. The result of the surveys conducted after each talk indicated that they were well-liked, and added value to their field of interest. The conference provided a joint venue for the established and early career researchers as well as Ph.D. students to share their research findings and learn from experts in the field of ordinary differential equations, partial differential equations, and their applications as well as numerical computations. The coffee breaks, dinner, and the breakfast provided informal venues for the participants to share their findings, discuss further actions in their ongoing projects as well as develop new research collaborations. The NSF funding provided financial support to 41 participants which included Ph.D. students, early career mathematicians, and mathematicians from underrepresented groups so they could benefit from the conference talks and discover new collaboration opportunities.  

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2019
Modified by: Ramjee Sharma
